channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Afghan Chief Executive Abdullah Denounces President Ghani as Unfit for Office
item.media:description: Afghanistan’s president, Ashraf Ghani, left, and chief executive, Abdullah Abdullah, at the NATO meeting in Poland last month.
item.description: Comments by the chief executive, Abdullah Abdullah, dealt a serious blow to the fragile power-sharing arrangement brokered by the United States.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL

item.title: Thailand Bombings Kill 4 and Wound Dozens, Most at Tourist Sites
item.media:description: An investigator at the scene of a bomb blast in the resort city of Hua Hin, Thailand, on Friday. Between Thursday night and Friday morning, several explosions were reported in Hua Hin, on the resort island of Phuket and in Surat Thani, Trang and Phang Nga Provinces.
item.media:credit: Munir Uz Zaman/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: The stricken areas included the coastal resort of Hua Hin and the island of Phuket. A Thai official called the attacks the work of “the same network.”
item.dc:creator: POYPITI AMATATHAM

item.title: Abroad in America: American Muslims and the Politics of Division
item.media:description: Khizr Khan, with his wife, Ghazala, during his address last month at the Democratic National Convention in Philadelphia, in which he delivered a rebuke to Donald J. Trump.
item.description: The rise of Donald J. Trump, as well as a Muslim immigrant’s stern rebuke of the Republican nominee, has stirred a debate on what it means for Muslims to be considered “good” Americans.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH

item.title: Beyond Olympic Glow, a Vicious Drug War Rages in Rio
item.media:description: Children playing soccer in the Complexo do Alemão, a sprawling patchwork of slums in Rio de Janeiro.
item.media:credit: Lalo de Almeida for The New York Times
item.description: In Rio de Janeiro’s sprawling slums, gang fights and police raids provide a stark contrast to the excitement of the Olympic Games happening just across the city.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO

item.title: U.N. Agrees on Draft of Resolution to Bolster Peacekeeping in South Sudan
item.media:description: Soldiers with the United Nations Mission in South Sudan in Juba last month. United Nations soldiers and aid workers have been repeatedly harassed and attacked, and in some cases killed.
item.media:credit: Eric Kanalstein/U.N. Mission in Sudan, via Associated Press
item.description: The document represents a robust action by the Security Council, invoking its rarely used coercive power to intervene when international peace and security are thought to be threatened.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: 2 Polio Paralysis Cases in Nigeria Set Back Eradication Effort
item.media:description: A child received a polio vaccine in Nigeria in April 2014.
item.description: The discovery dashed the hopes of global health authorities who had wanted to declare the continent polio-free soon.
item.dc:creator: DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.

item.title: Ben-Gurion on Israel, Peace and Back Pain: A Lost Interview Is Brought to Life
item.media:description: The first prime minister of Israel, David Ben-Gurion, at his home in 1972 on the eve of his 86th birthday.
item.description: In a recently rediscovered interview, David Ben-Gurion spoke of state-building, the biblical prophets that guided him and Israel’s quest for security.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Military Officials Distorted ISIS Intelligence, Congressional Panel Says
item.media:description: Gen. Lloyd J. Austin III, Centcom commander at the time, at a hearing before the Senate last year, giving what many lawmakers considered an overly positive assessment of the war.
item.description: The United States Central Command altered its analysis to portray a more optimistic picture of the war than events in Iraq and Syria warranted, a report concluded.
item.dc:creator: HELENE COOPER
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: British Girl Who Joined ISIS Is Reported Killed in Airstrike
item.media:description: Kadiza Sultana, a British schoolgirl, in a video still of her passing through security at Gatwick Airport last year before she and two fellow teenagers boarded a flight to Turkey and then a bus to Syria.
item.description: Kadiza Sultana, one of three British schoolgirls who left home last year to join the Islamic State, is believed to have been killed in Syria.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE and MONA EL-NAGGAR
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: The Interpreter: Signs of Trouble in Ukraine Prompt Question: What’s Vladimir Putin Up To?
item.media:description: Ukrainian military members on the front lines in eastern Ukraine, near the city of Avdeyevka.
item.description: A recent attack in Crimea serves as a familiar parallel to the way Russia behaved just before previous military action against Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: MAX FISHER

item.title: Germany Proposes Tougher Measures to Combat Terrorism
item.description: The interior minister outlined a package of plans that included closer monitoring of refugees and making it a crime to express sympathy for terrorism.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE

item.title: What in the World: A Tough Sell, Even in Russia: Ivan the Not-So-Terrible
item.media:description: Ivan the Terrible And His Son Ivan, November 16th 1581 by Ilya Repin
item.description: A Russian governor plans to erect a statue to honor the notorious czar, but many in his region are not impressed.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR

item.title: The Persistence of Chlorine Gas Attacks in Syria
item.media:description: A civilian in a hospital on Thursday after what medical and civil defense officials said was a chlorine gas attack in a neighborhood of Aleppo, Syria, that killed four people.
item.description: The use of chlorine gas against civilians in the Syrian city of Aleppo should be investigated as a “war crime,” a United Nations diplomat said Thursday.
item.dc:creator: RUSSELL GOLDMAN
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: With Congress Deadlocked, White House Diverts Funds to Fight Zika
item.media:description: President Obama and Sylvia Mathews Burwell, the secretary of health and human services, discussed the government’s response to the Zika virus in July.
item.description: The Obama administration said $81 million will be shifted to the development of a Zika vaccine, citing a failure by Congress to approve new funding.
item.dc:creator: JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

item.title: Mounties Cite ‘Race Against Time’ in Thwarting ISIS Supporter’s Attack
item.media:description: Video of Aaron Driver was shown on Thursday in a news conference on what the Royal Canadian Mounted Police were calling a terrorism episode that occurred on Wednesday in Strathroy, Ontario.
item.media:credit: Justin Tang/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.description: The authorities said they first had to identify a man in a video who threatened an assault. They found him shortly before he detonated a bomb in a taxi.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Snapchat ‘Anime’ Effect Is Criticized as Asian Caricature
item.media:description: Snapchat says this filter is inspired by anime, but some observers say it’s racially insensitive.
item.description: The app is once again under fire about a racial lens. This time the complaints involve “yellowface.”
item.dc:creator: KATIE ROGERS

item.title: I.M.F. Lends $12 Billion to Egypt to Fix Ailing Economy
item.media:description: An Egyptian woman carried her son as she made her way past a shop window saying “great sale” in Arabic in downtown Cairo on Tuesday.
item.description: The International Monetary Fund agreed to grant Egypt the loan over three years to help stabilize its currency and reduce its budget deficit.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Indian State to License Cow Protection Groups to Aid Police
item.media:description: A Hindu woman outside a temple in Allahabad, India, on Sunday. Hindus venerate cows, and cow protection groups are suspected of attacking people of religious minorities.
item.description: The move comes days after the prime minister denounced vigilante types of such groups, which have targeted Muslims and others suspected of killing cows, considered sacred in Hinduism.
item.dc:creator: SUHASINI RAJ

item.title: No, Google Says, It Did Not Delete ‘Palestine’ From Its Maps
item.media:description: The West Bank city of Bethlehem, right, separated from Jerusalem by the Israeli barrier in February.
item.description: There is a social media storm of outrage about the removal of a “Palestine” label, but Google says the label was not there in the first place.
item.dc:creator: LIAM STACK

item.title: ISIS Fighters Are Still Lurking in Surt, Libyan Officials Warn
item.media:description: Pro-government fighters last month near the Ouagadougou Center, which had served as the Islamic State’s headquarters in Surt, Libya.
item.description: Officials of the pro-government militias that seized most of Surt on Wednesday said hundreds of Islamic State fighters were hiding in three neighborhoods.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND and NOUR YOUSSEF
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Japan Exults as Kohei Uchimura, Gymnast Called ‘the King,’ Expands His Empire
item.media:description: Kohei Uchimura on the parallel bars during the men’s individual all-around event. Uchimura won his second consecutive Olympic gold medal in the event.
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.description: With the next Summer Games scheduled in Tokyo in 2020, the pressure on Mr. Uchimura to keep his gymnastics magic going will be huge.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN SOBLE

item.title: Sinosphere: Contentious Issues Will Follow Sun Yang and Mack Horton Into Olympic Pool
item.media:description: Mack Horton of Australia, left, edged out Sun Yang of China, center, in the 400-meter freestyle final on Saturday.
item.description: Mr. Horton, of Australia, called Mr. Sun, of China, a “drug cheat” and then defeated him to take Olympic gold. The two meet again in the water on Friday.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: Explosion at Coal-Fired Plant in Central China Kills at Least 21
item.description: A high-pressure steam pipe blew up at a plant in the city of Dangyang in Hubei Province, according to a news website run by the provincial government.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG

item.title: Bratislava Journal: A Renewed Cafe Culture Perks Up Bratislava’s Old Town
item.media:description: Urban House in Bratislava, Slovakia. Modern cafes have ushered in a revival of a grand cafe culture, which was interrupted during the Communist era, when the authorities tried to limit social interaction.
item.media:credit: Akos Stiller for The New York Times
item.description: The new scene has ushered in a revival of tradition that was interrupted during the Communist era, when officials tried to limit social interaction.
item.dc:creator: MIROSLAVA GERMANOVA

item.title: Google Fined for Breaking Russian Antitrust Rules With Android
item.media:description: Smartphones on display at a Google event in San Francisco.
item.description: The search giant’s mobile operating system was found to have unfairly favored digital services like Google Maps over those of Russian rivals.
item.dc:creator: MARK SCOTT

item.title: Zambia Votes Amid Economic Slowdown and Political Violence
item.media:description: Supporters of the main Zambian opposition leader, Hakainde Hichilema, at his last presidential campaign rally in Lusaka on Wednesday.
item.description: President Edgar Lungu, who won a special election last year, is seeking a full term in a country whose copper-reliant economy has been hurt by weaker demand from China.
item.dc:creator: NORIMITSU ONISHI

item.title: Russia, in Military Exercise, Pits Fog of War Against Dogs of War
item.description: Severomorsk, home to a naval base and roughly 50,000 people, is shrouded in smoke and fumes for a three-day military exercise.
item.dc:creator: LINCOLN PIGMAN

item.title: Sinosphere: The Exuberant Chinese Swimmer Who Has Become a Star at Rio
item.media:description: The Chinese swimmer Fu Yuanhui, left, with the bronze medal she won in the women’s 100-meter backstroke event.
item.description: Fu Yuanhui won a bronze medal for China in the 100-meter backstroke and has won fans for her unabashed joy at competing in the Games.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Deadly Wildfires on Portuguese Island of Madeira Reach Its Largest City
item.description: The biggest fire rapidly encroached on the residential outskirts of Funchal, home to about 110,000 people, and there were nearly 200 blazes on the mainland.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: What in the World: Sending Mail in Mongolia? ‘Dissident.sloth.ploy’ Could Be the Address
item.description: Oddly poetic three-word codes will soon act as addresses in Mongolia, one of the world’s most sparsely populated nations.
item.dc:creator: BRYANT ROUSSEAU

item.title: Julian Assange to Be Questioned by Sweden Over Rape Claim, Ecuador Says
item.media:description: Julian Assange, shown in February, was granted political asylum by Ecuador in 2012 after his appeal against extradition to Sweden was denied, and he has been confined to its London embassy ever since.
item.description: The WikiLeaks founder was granted political asylum by the Ecuadoreans in 2012, and he has been confined to its London embassy ever since.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Australia Rejects Bids From Chinese Investors for Electricity Provider
item.media:description: Electric power lines near Muswellbrook, Australia, a part of the state of New South Wales that is served by Ausgrid.
item.description: Treasurer Scott Morrison said that allowing a deal to go through with bidders from Hong Kong or the mainland would be “contrary to the national interest.”
item.dc:creator: NEIL GOUGH

item.title: Opinion: How the Most Dangerous Place on Earth Got Safer
item.media:description: Children play in an abandoned structure by a soccer field in the Rivera Hernández neighborhood in San Pedro Sula, Honduras. Gangs used to frequent this building — a girl walking home from high school was kidnapped by gang members and then brought here and raped two years ago — and the soccer field used to be a place to bury bodies.
item.media:credit: Katie Orlinsky for The New York Times
item.description: Programs funded by the United States are helping transform Honduras. Who says American power is dead?
item.dc:creator: SONIA NAZARIO

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: For Migrants, an Olympic Village in Ruins
item.description: Greece is housing some 2,000 Afghan and other migrants in crumbling stadiums left over from the Games of 2004. The biggest complaint: boredom.
item.dc:creator: DOVE BARBANEL
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Editorial: The Cost of Political Instability in Nepal
item.media:description: Nepal earthquake victims in a displacement camp in Kathmandu.
item.description: Continuing changes in leadership have led to stalled progress on trade issues, fairness to ethnic groups and recovery from last year’s earthquake.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD

item.title: Afghanistan Is in Chaos. Is That What Hamid Karzai Wants?
item.media:description: Hamid Karzai, the former president of Afghanistan, at his compound in Kabul last month.
item.media:credit: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
item.description: Critics say the former president is working from the wings to destabilize his successor’s government. He says he has no interest in returning to power.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL

item.title: Talking to Terrorists
item.media:description: Harry Sarfo, a former Islamic State fighter from Germany, inside the maximum-security prison in Bremen where he is serving a three-year sentence on terrorism charges.
item.media:credit: Gordon Welters for The New York Times
item.description: For once, the conversation wasn’t via social media, and the name the Islamic State defector used was the one on his birth certificate.
item.dc:creator: RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Outstanding Issues: A Yemeni Teenager’s Trip to Estonia, by Way of Guantánamo
item.media:description: Ahmed Abdul Qader, a former Guantánamo Bay detainee, at Freedom Square in Tallinn, Estonia, in May.
item.media:credit: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
item.description: The reporter Charlie Savage wrote about an ex-Guantánamo inmate’s resettlement; the story didn’t end when the article published.
item.dc:creator: CHARLIE SAVAGE

item.title: At the Front in a Scarred Falluja
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.description: Bryan Denton, a photographer who works for The New York Times and is based in Beirut, Lebanon, gives his account of covering Iraqi forces’ recapture of Falluja from the Islamic State.
item.dc:creator: BRYAN DENTON
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Devanampattinam Journal: Mortal to Divine and Back: India’s Transgender Goddesses
item.description: During the 10-day Hindu festival Mayana Kollai, the troubles of transgender women are distant as they transform into the deities they worship and are revered by villagers.
item.dc:creator: Photographs by CANDACE FEIT

item.title: Not Forgotten: Inside The Times Archives
item.description: Since 1851, more than 200,000 people have been the subjects of obituaries in The New York Times. Join us each day this summer as we revisit many of these memorable lives.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Voices From Europe’s Far Right
item.media:description: “Our economy doesn’t increase along with the never-ending supply of immigrants,” wrote Mikael Jakobsen, 24, a law student in Aarhus, Denmark.
item.media:credit: Michael Drost-Hansen for The New York Times
item.description: Hundreds of readers from across the Continent responded to our call to share their experiences as supporters of far-right parties.
item.dc:creator: PALKO KARASZ
